what: Downloading and Cleaning U.S. Macroeconomic Data
title: Downloading and Cleaning U.S. Macroeconomic Data
text: Utilities retrieve tidy U.S. macroeconomic data series public government data providers. Functions streamline access series Federal Reserve Bank St. Louis Federal Reserve Economic Data (FRED), Bureau Labor Statistics (BLS) flat files, Bureau Economic Analysis (BEA) National Income Product Accounts (NIPA) tables, return consistent, tidy data frames ready modeling graphics. package includes helpers date alignment, log-linear projections, common macro diagnostics, along convenience plot builders quick publication-quality charts.

title: Downloading and Cleaning U.S. Macroeconomic Data
Downloading and Cleaning U.S. Macroeconomic Data
text: Downloads merges economic data series Federal Reserve Economic Data (FRED) API.
code: # Named arguments give friendly column names fred_data <- getFRED(prime_epop = "LNS12300060", cpi = "CPIAUCSL")  # Unnamed arguments use lowercase ticker as column name fred_data <- getFRED("UNRATE", "PAYEMS")

title: Downloading and Cleaning U.S. Macroeconomic Data

title: Downloading and Cleaning U.S. Macroeconomic Data
text: Creates intelligent date breaks ggplot2 always include last data point.
code: ggplot(data, aes(date, value)) +   geom_line() +   scale_x_date(breaks = date_breaks_gg(n = 6, last = max(data$date)))

title: Downloading and Cleaning U.S. Macroeconomic Data
text: Generates evenly spaced date breaks selecting every nth unique date.
code: ggplot(data, aes(date, value)) +   geom_line() +   scale_x_date(breaks = date_breaks_n(data$date, n = 6))

what: Date breaks anchored to last data month (for ggplot) — date_breaks_gg
title: Date breaks anchored to last data month (for ggplot) — date_breaks_gg
text: Create breaks function scale_x_date() always includes last actual data month selects every nth month counting backward.

title: Date breaks anchored to last data month (for ggplot) — date_breaks_gg
Date breaks anchored to last data month (for ggplot) — date_breaks_gg
text: n Integer; keep every n-th month counting backward last. Default 6. last Date; last (max) date data. Required ensure break placed actual data. decreasing Logical; TRUE, return breaks descending order. Default FALSE.

title: Date breaks anchored to last data month (for ggplot) — date_breaks_gg
text: function usable scale_x_date(breaks = ...).

title: Date breaks anchored to last data month (for ggplot) — date_breaks_gg
code: # Minimal reproducible example (avoid using the name `df`, which masks stats::df) set.seed(1) dat <- data.frame(   date  = seq(as.Date("2023-01-01"), by = "month", length.out = 24),   value = cumsum(rnorm(24)) )  library(ggplot2)  ggplot(dat, aes(date, value)) +   geom_line() +   scale_x_date(     date_labels = "%b\n%Y",     breaks = date_breaks_gg(n = 6, last = max(dat$date))   ) +   labs(x = NULL, y = NULL)

title: Create evenly spaced breaks — date_breaks_n
text: Generate sequence date breaks ggplot scales, taking every nth unique date.

title: Create evenly spaced breaks — date_breaks_n
Create evenly spaced breaks — date_breaks_n
text: dates vector dates. n Integer, keep every n-th date (default = 6). decreasing Logical, TRUE (default) sorts dates descending order.

title: Create evenly spaced breaks — date_breaks_n
text: vector dates suitable use ggplot2 axis breaks.

title: Create evenly spaced breaks — date_breaks_n
code: library(ggplot2) library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: ‘dplyr’ #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:stats’: #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:base’: #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union  df <- tibble(   date = seq.Date(as.Date("2020-01-01"), as.Date("2025-01-01"), by = "month"),   value = rnorm(61) )  ggplot(df, aes(date, value)) +   geom_line() +   scale_x_date(breaks = date_breaks_n(df$date, 6))

what: Download and Process Bureau of Labor Statistics Data — getBLSFiles
title: Download and Process Bureau of Labor Statistics Data — getBLSFiles
text: Downloads processes data Bureau Labor Statistics (BLS) flat files. Supports multiple data sources including CPI, ECI, JOLTS, CPS, CES, others. function retrieves main data file along associated metadata files, merges , returns tidy tibble ready analysis.

title: Download and Process Bureau of Labor Statistics Data — getBLSFiles
Download and Process Bureau of Labor Statistics Data — getBLSFiles
text: data_source Character string specifying BLS data source. Available options: "cpi" Consumer Price Index - current data "eci" Employment Cost Index (quarterly) "cex" Consumer Expenditure Survey "jolts" Job Openings Labor Turnover Survey "cps" Current Population Survey "ces" Current Employment Statistics - series "ces_allemp" Current Employment Statistics - employees, seasonally adjusted "ces_total" Current Employment Statistics - total nonfarm employment "averageprice" Average price data - current "food" Average price data - food items "se" State metro area employment "su" State local area unemployment email Character string email address. Required BLS identifying API users. Set HTTP User-Agent header.

title: Download and Process Bureau of Labor Statistics Data — getBLSFiles
text: tibble containing merged data columns : series_id Unique identifier data series date Observation date value Numeric data value ... Additional metadata columns vary data source (e.g., item codes, industry codes, area codes)

title: Download and Process Bureau of Labor Statistics Data — getBLSFiles
text: function constructs URLs BLS flat files https://download.bls.gov/pub/time.series/, downloads series metadata auxiliary lookup tables, downloads merges main data file. Date parsing handles monthly (sources) quarterly (ECI) data frequencies.

title: Download and Process Bureau of Labor Statistics Data — getBLSFiles
code: # \donttest{   # Download CPI data   cpi_data <- getBLSFiles("cpi", "your.email@example.com") #> Downloading series file... #> Downloading file: item #> Downloading file: area #> Downloading main data file: data.0.Current #> Warning: There was 1 warning in `dplyr::mutate()`. #> ℹ In argument: `value = as.numeric(value)`. #> Caused by warning: #> ! NAs introduced by coercion #> Merging main data with series metadata...    # Download JOLTS data   jolts_data <- getBLSFiles("jolts", "your.email@example.com") #> Downloading series file... #> Downloading file: industry #> Downloading file: state #> Downloading file: dataelement #> Downloading file: sizeclass #> Downloading main data file: data.1.AllItems #> Warning: One or more parsing issues, call `problems()` on your data frame for details, #> e.g.: #>   dat <- vroom(...) #>   problems(dat) #> Merging main data with series metadata... # }

what: Download and Merge FRED Series — getFRED
title: Download and Merge FRED Series — getFRED
text: flexible wrapper downloads one data series St. Louis Fed (FRED) API, optionally computes one-period percentage changes, merges tidy tibble keyed date.

title: Download and Merge FRED Series — getFRED
code: getFRED(..., keep_all = TRUE, rename_variables = NULL, lagged = NULL)

title: Download and Merge FRED Series — getFRED
text: ... One FRED series IDs.  element may either Unnamed character string raw FRED ticker; column keeps lowercase ticker name, e.g.\ "UNRATE". Named character string value FRED ticker name becomes column label, e.g.\ payroll = "PAYEMS". may also pass single character vector (named unnamed) compatibility older code. keep_all Logical.  TRUE (default) performs full join keeps dates across series; FALSE performs inner join. rename_variables Optional character vector new column names (one per series), retained backward compatibility.  Supply either argument names ..., . lagged Logical scalar logical vector.  TRUE (corresponding element TRUE), series replaced one-period percentage change \((x_t / x_{t-1}) - 1\).  Recycled match number series length 1.

title: Download and Merge FRED Series — getFRED
text: tibble date column one column per requested series.

title: Download and Merge FRED Series — getFRED
text: may supply series two ways: Natural “...” style: getFRED(unrate = "UNRATE", payroll = "PAYEMS"). Named arguments give friendly column names; unnamed arguments keep (lower-case) ticker column name. Legacy style: pass single (optionally named) character vector—e.g.\ c(unrate = "UNRATE", payroll = "PAYEMS")—/use rename_variables= argument.  remains supported backward compatibility. provide names ... non-NULL rename_variables vector, function stops prompts choose single naming method.

title: Download and Merge FRED Series — getFRED

what: Download and Process BEA NIPA Files with Fast Row Expansion — getNIPAFiles
title: Download and Process BEA NIPA Files with Fast Row Expansion — getNIPAFiles
text: function downloads processes National Income Product Accounts (NIPA) data files BEA website. reads necessary register files, formats date column, uses fast stringi functions together tidyr's unnest() split combined TableId:LineNo field separate rows columns. Finally, merges datasets.

title: Download and Process BEA NIPA Files with Fast Row Expansion — getNIPAFiles
Download and Process BEA NIPA Files with Fast Row Expansion — getNIPAFiles
text: location URL path BEA files located. Default: "https://apps.bea.gov/national/Release/TXT/". type character string indicating type data load. example, "Q" quarterly "M" monthly data. Default "Q".

title: Download and Process BEA NIPA Files with Fast Row Expansion — getNIPAFiles
text: data frame containing merged formatted NIPA data.

title: Download and Process BEA NIPA Files with Fast Row Expansion — getNIPAFiles
code: # \donttest{   nipadata <- getNIPAFiles(type = "Q") #> Start time: 2026-02-06 01:20:56.058559 #> Loading Q data from https://apps.bea.gov/national/Release/TXT//nipadataQ.txt #> Formatting date column... #> Splitting TableId:LineNo using stringi and unnesting... #> End time: 2026-02-06 01:21:08.094141 # }

what: Load and Process Personal Consumption Expenditures (PCE) Inflation Data — getPCEInflation
title: Load and Process Personal Consumption Expenditures (PCE) Inflation Data — getPCEInflation
text: Downloads processes BEA NIPA data compute Personal Consumption Expenditures (PCE) price indices weights growth measures. Federal Reserve's preferred inflation measure.

title: Load and Process Personal Consumption Expenditures (PCE) Inflation Data — getPCEInflation
Load and Process Personal Consumption Expenditures (PCE) Inflation Data — getPCEInflation
text: frequency Character string indicating frequency data. Defaults "M" (monthly). NIPA_data Optional data frame. provided, used raw NIPA dataset instead loading fresh data getNIPAFiles().'

title: Load and Process Personal Consumption Expenditures (PCE) Inflation Data — getPCEInflation
text: tbl_df (data frame) containing PCE data calculated variables.

title: Load and Process Personal Consumption Expenditures (PCE) Inflation Data — getPCEInflation
text: function performs following steps: Loads NIPA data using getNIPAFiles (uses pre-loaded data). Extracts total PCE table "U20405" (series code "DPCERC"). Computes PCE component weights nominal consumption share (component value divided total PCE). Extracts quantity indices table "U20403". Loads price indices table "U20404", joins weights quantities, calculates period--period growth measures.

title: Load and Process Personal Consumption Expenditures (PCE) Inflation Data — getPCEInflation
code: # \donttest{   # Load monthly PCE data   pce_data <- getPCEInflation("M") #> Start time: 2026-02-06 01:21:08.207363 #> Loading M data from https://apps.bea.gov/national/Release/TXT//nipadataM.txt #> Formatting date column... #> Splitting TableId:LineNo using stringi and unnesting... #> End time: 2026-02-06 01:21:19.090909 # }

what: Get Full Unemployment Rate from FRED — getUnrateFRED
title: Get Full Unemployment Rate from FRED — getUnrateFRED
text: Downloads civilian unemployment level labor force level FRED, calculates unemployment rate \(\text{unemploy\_level} / \text{lf\_level}\).

title: Get Full Unemployment Rate from FRED — getUnrateFRED
Get Full Unemployment Rate from FRED — getUnrateFRED
text: tibble columns: date Observation date unemploy_level Civilian unemployment level (thousands) lf_level Civilian labor force level (thousands) full_unrate Unemployment rate (decimal)

title: Get Full Unemployment Rate from FRED — getUnrateFRED
Log-Linear Projection (data-masked, dplyr-native) — logLinearProjection
text: Fits log-linear trend log(value) ~ t calibration window projects rows /start_date. Designed use inside dplyr verbs (need pass .).

title: Log-Linear Projection (data-masked, dplyr-native) — logLinearProjection
code: logLinearProjection(   date,   value,   start_date,   end_date,   group = NULL,   data = NULL )

title: Log-Linear Projection (data-masked, dplyr-native) — logLinearProjection
text: date Bare column name date variable (coercible Date). value Bare column name positive numeric series project. start_date Date string coercible Date; start calibration. end_date Date string coercible Date; end calibration. group Optional bare column name group projecting. data Optional data frame. omitted, uses current data mask (e.g., inside mutate()) via dplyr::cur_data_all().

title: Log-Linear Projection (data-masked, dplyr-native) — logLinearProjection
text: numeric vector projection aligned input rows; NA start_date. Respects grouping group supplied.
